OLS Estimator

f(β)=12∣∣y−Xβ∣∣2=12(y−Xβ)T(y−Xβ)f(\beta) = \frac{1}{2}||y-X\beta||^2 = \frac{1}{2}(y-X\beta)^T(y-X\beta)f(β)=21​∣∣y−Xβ∣∣2=21​(y−Xβ)T(y−Xβ)

We want to minimize the objective function with respect to β\betaβ. The objective function is convex f′′>0f'' > 0f′′>0, so there is a unique global minimizer.

Assumptions: XXX is full rank (i.e., no multi-collinearity). If XXX is not full rank, then we have a non-unique solution.

β^=arg⁡min⁡β{12(y−Xβ)T(y−Xβ)}\hat{\beta} = \underset{\beta}{\arg \min} \left\{\frac{1}{2}(y-X\beta)^T(y-X\beta)\right\}β^​=βargmin​{21​(y−Xβ)T(y−Xβ)}

β^=(XTX)−1XTy\hat{\beta} = (X^TX)^{-1}X^Tyβ^​=(XTX)−1XTy

(XTX)β^=XTy(X^TX)\hat{\beta} = X^Ty(XTX)β^​=XTy

If we have the matrix of XXX and vector yyy, then the OLS estimator is very easy to compute. The overall computation cost is O(nk2+k3)O(nk^2 + k^3)O(nk2+k3) because:

  • Solving XTyX^TyXTy is O(nk)O(nk)O(nk).
  • Solving XTXX^TXXTX is O(nk2)O(nk^2)O(nk2).
  • Solving (XTX)β^=XTy(X^TX)\hat{\beta} = X^Ty(XTX)β^​=XTy is O(k3)O(k^3)O(k3)

Robust Regression

f(β)=∣∣y−Xβ∣∣1=∑i=1n∣yi−Xiβ∣f(\beta) = ||y-X\beta||_1 = \sum_{i=1}^n |y_i-X_i\beta|f(β)=∣∣y−Xβ∣∣1​=∑i=1n​∣yi​−Xi​β∣

Sum of squared errors is sensitive to outliers while the L1 norm of error is not influenced by outliers. The idea is that the sum of squared errors for outliers will be much greater than the absolute error.

Brittle Regression

f(β)=∣∣y−Xβ∣∣∞=max⁡{∣yi−Xiβ∣}f(\beta) = ||y-X\beta||_\infty = \max\{|y_i-X_i\beta|\}f(β)=∣∣y−Xβ∣∣∞​=max{∣yi​−Xi​β∣}

max⁡{∣yi−Xiβ∣}≈log⁡(∑i=1nexp⁡(yi−Xiβ))\max\{|y_i-X_i\beta|\} \approx \log{\left(\sum_{i=1}^n\exp{(y_i-X_i\beta)}\right)}max{∣yi​−Xi​β∣}≈log(∑i=1n​exp(yi​−Xi​β))

The brittle regression would be very sensitive to outliers. Therefore, if we want to have a line of best fit through the outliers we would minimize this objective function.

Lasso

f(β)=12∣∣y−Xβ∣∣2+α∣∣β∣∣1f(\beta) = \frac{1}{2}||y-X\beta||^2 + \alpha||\beta||_1f(β)=21​∣∣y−Xβ∣∣2+α∣∣β∣∣1​

∣∣β∣∣1=∑i=1k∣βk∣||\beta||_1 = \sum_{i=1}^k|\beta_k|∣∣β∣∣1​=∑i=1k​∣βk​∣ (i.e., L1 norm - sum of all absolute values) and α\alphaα is the regularization parameter. Now the objective function has the squared error + size of βi\beta_iβi​s. Therefore, the bigger each βi\beta_iβi​ term is, the more penalty we will have on the objective function. So in order to minimize the objective function, we would want to shrink some of the βi\beta_iβi​s.

β^Lasso=arg⁡min⁡β{12∣∣y−Xβ∣∣2+α∣∣β∣∣1}\hat{\beta}_{Lasso} = \underset{\beta}{\arg \min}\left\{\frac{1}{2}||y-X\beta||^2 + \alpha||\beta||_1\right\}β^​Lasso​=βargmin​{21​∣∣y−Xβ∣∣2+α∣∣β∣∣1​}

Note that the L1 norm is not differentiable at the minimum point (i.e., it is convex, but it is not smooth). However, there is still a closed form for β^Lasso\hat{\beta}_{Lasso}β^​Lasso​.

Minimizing the objective function will allow us to shrink some βi\beta_iβi​ such that ∣β^i∣=0|\hat{\beta}_i| = 0∣β^​i​∣=0 for some iii's. This in turn is useful for feature selection. The higher the α\alphaα is, the more feature we would shrink β\betaβ.

Ridge

f(β)=12∣∣y−Xβ∣∣2+α2∣∣β∣∣2f(\beta) = \frac{1}{2}||y-X\beta||^2 + \frac{\alpha}{2}||\beta||^2f(β)=21​∣∣y−Xβ∣∣2+2α​∣∣β∣∣2

Instead of the L1 norm like we used in lasso, we use the L2 norm of the β\betaβ for the penalizing term.

β^Ridge=arg⁡min⁡β{12∣∣y−Xβ∣∣2+α2∣∣β∣∣2}\hat{\beta}_{Ridge} = \underset{\beta}{\arg \min}\left\{\frac{1}{2}||y-X\beta||^2 + \frac{\alpha}{2}||\beta||^2\right\}β^​Ridge​=βargmin​{21​∣∣y−Xβ∣∣2+2α​∣∣β∣∣2}

β^Ridge=(XTX+αI)−1XTy\hat{\beta}_{Ridge} = (X^TX + \alpha I)^{-1}X^Tyβ^​Ridge​=(XTX+αI)−1XTy

Note that XTX+αIX^TX + \alpha IXTX+αI is always full rank, so ridge regression can be a solution for multicollinear data.

The Ridge regression will make the model less sensitive to overfitting. This implies that as α\alphaα increases the test error decreases.

What we want is a 0-1 loss, but this is hard to minimize. Therefore use the Hinge loss for a convex approximation of the 0-1 loss.
